title: 105_s448
content: The Act titled "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" addresses the interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste under the Solid Waste Disposal Act. It introduces a new section, SEC. 4011, to regulate this aspect. The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" prohibits out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal without local government authorization. Authorization must be granted formally, recorded in writing, and final before receiving the waste. Prior to granting authorization for out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal, affected local governments must require facility owners to provide detailed information about the facility's size, waste capacity, and anticipated waste quantities. This information must be made available for inspection by the Governor, adjoining local governments, Indian tribes, and other interested parties. The facility owner must provide detailed information about the facility site, including maps showing location, environmental characteristics, and proposed environmental controls. This information is required before authorization for out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal can be granted. The facility owner must provide detailed information about environmental controls, site access controls, required permits, and personnel requirements for the facility. The facility owner must provide information on personnel requirements, including skill and education levels, as well as details on violations of environmental laws and required disclosures on gifts and contributions as per State law. The facility owner must provide information on personnel requirements, violations of environmental laws, and required disclosures on gifts and contributions as per State law before taking formal action on granting authorization to receive out-of-State municipal solid waste. Prior notification to the Governor, adjoining local governments, and Indian tribes is also required. The local government must publish notice of the proposed action in a newspaper and provide an opportunity for public comment, including a public hearing. They must also notify the Governor, adjoining local governments, and Indian tribes of any authorization granted. Landfills and incinerators are exempt from these requirements if they have been in operation or under construction for the past year. The exemption from certain requirements for landfills and incinerators is based on receiving out-of-State waste or having legal authorization from local government. Compliance with design, location standards, and environmental laws is necessary for landfills. The exemption for landfills and incinerators is contingent on compliance with federal and state laws regarding design, location standards, leachate collection, groundwater monitoring, and financial assurance. Documentation of waste shipments must be provided to the state Governor. The Governor has the authority to restrict out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills by limiting the quantity received for disposal in response to written requests from local governments and solid waste planning units. The Governor can restrict out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills by limiting the quantity received for disposal based on written requests from local governments and solid waste planning units. Prior to submitting a request, affected parties must provide notice and opportunity for public comment. The Governor must respond consistently to requests from local governments regarding out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal, without discrimination based on landfill or state of origin. The Governor's authority is limited by state law and must not contradict it. The Governor's authority to regulate out-of-state waste disposal is limited by state law and existing contracts. Landfill or incinerator operators must make their disposal contracts available for public inspection in the affected community. Landfill or incinerator operators must make disposal contracts available for public inspection in the affected community, with key details such as volume of waste, source, and contract duration. States can become exempt from this requirement by notifying the Administrator. States can be exempt from the requirement to make disposal contracts for landfills or incinerators available for public inspection by notifying the Administrator and making specific reference to the section. The Administrator will acknowledge the exemption upon receiving the notification. Definitions in this section include "affected local government" and "affected local solid waste planning unit." The curr_chunk defines terms related to solid waste management, such as affected local solid waste planning unit, host agreement, and municipal solid waste. It outlines the primary jurisdiction over the use of land for facilities and the definition of municipal solid waste generated from various sources. The curr_chunk defines municipal solid waste as solid waste generated from residential, commercial, institutional, or industrial sources, including paper, wood, yard wastes, food wastes, plastics, leather, rubber, and other materials. Exclusions are hazardous waste, industrial waste, medical waste, recyclable materials, and returned materials. The curr_chunk defines terms related to waste management, including out-of-state municipal solid waste and owner or operator definitions for landfills and incinerators. The curr_chunk adds a new item to the table of contents of the Solid Waste Disposal Act related to waste management definitions.
